metadata.title: Abortion in Argentina and Mexico
metadata.subtitle: What Can We Learn About the Public Debate on Abortion in Argentina vs. in Mexico From Newspaper and Social Media Analysis?
metadata.abstract: This analysis discusses the public debate on abortion in Argentina and Mexico using data from newspapers and Twitter. Abortion laws continue to be very restrictive across Latin America and the legalisation of abortion is often framed as a demand by national feminist movements. In Argentina, abortion was legalised in December 2020, whereas Mexico has a very fragmented, restrictive legal system. The collected data and different types of analysis including topic modelling, demography analysis, and semantic network mapping offer an overview of the ongoing debate and the key differences between the two countries, which include, for example, the prominence and fragmentation of the debate in both countries. The analysis indicates that Argentina might have a more unified and active pro-abortion movement than Mexico, which also explains their recent legislative success.

blocks.text: The distinguishing feature of the ‘fourth wave’ of feminism in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) has been its use of social media.  This is not to say that advancements in gender parity have been minimal, fleeting or relegated to the online world. Rather it has galvanised a transnational feminist network in the region to problematise the relationship between the state and the female body.

In opposition to the multiple forms of structural violence on female and feminised bodies, regional feminist discourse and activism disrupts accepted political norms. It achieves this by taking a biological-political ideological stance which centres itself on the female body.  The creation of new ideological frames, new vocabulary, and new ways to relate to the State have permeated the once hard boundaries between Latin American countries. This is partly due to the use of social media, but also due to the realisation of shared realities of legal and judicial restrictions on female bodies in two particular areas; abortion and femicide.

One clear example is a song which originated in Chile and quickly became the unofficial anthem of the movement. It has spread around the world, depicting the transnational character of the movement and the importance of social media in spreading the message. "El violador eres tu" has become known globally for its powerful characteristic performances by blindfolded women in a number of major cities around the world.

The politicisation of the female body and the redefinition of violence against women as a societal structural problem reaching across State boundaries has been met with conservative resistance of a similar widespread and transnational nature, labelling it as ‘gender ideology.’  A feature of this countermovement is its homogeneity across the region. Particularly with regards to its alliances with religious sectors and its promotion of alternative frames of understanding gender-based issues, which omit politics using a renewed focus on the private sphere and familism.

The focus of our analysis will not be on the intellectual merits of these movements but rather on the public discourse of legalizing abortion as one of the key topics of feminist movements in Latin America. Furthermore, our analysis is geographically restricted to two important case studies on abortion legislation which stand out in the region for their cultural and political influence: Argentina and Mexico. Mexico has resisted national legalisation of abortion while Argentina legalised abortion nationwide in December 2020.

Our study regards less restrictive legislative change on the one hand, and no legislative change or restrictive legislative changes on the other as the threshold for the effectiveness of feminist and counter feminist social discourse. Maintaining this constant is important to better assess public discourse and its role in two substantively different contexts. This understanding leads us to broaden our research question into two related sections:
What can we learn about the public debate on abortion in Argentina vs. in Mexico from newspaper and social media analysis?
Can we discern any strategies and tactics from the various actors?

We hypothesise that our analysis will be able to discern some strategies related to public discourse. Traditional media outlets are said to be conservative while social media has become the main platform for new social movements in Latin America. This hypothesis will also be explored in respect to the pro-abortion and pro-life movements in Argentina and Mexico. A variety of digital media analysis techniques on several curated corpuses of data from local newspapers and Twitter will be used for our investigation.

The following section offers an insight into the current state of abortion law across Latin America, followed by the specific cases of Argentina and Mexico. It includes background information to contextualise the data analysis and provides an overview of the issue discussed in this analysis.

Under this section, the results from the different data analysis methods will be presented. This includes topic modelling of  newspaper data for Argentina and Mexico, demography analyses of Twitter data from both countries, and network mapping of all collected data.

The Demography analysis shows the use of certain key words over time. In our case, the frequency of key words connected to abortion is examined for the collected Twitter data in Mexico (September 2019 and December 2020) and Argentina (December 2020). The following list of words was used for the indexation of the data:

Indexing the datasets with the list of terms and running a demography analysis for each dataset offered valuable insights into the discourse on abortion on social media in Mexico and Argentina, respectively. The data of Mexico in September 2019, the month that abortion was legalised in Oaxaca, can be directly compared to the Tweets in December 2020, when abortion was legalised in Argentina. The following graph depicts the use of words in the tweets in Mexico in September 2019.

Compared to the use of the same terms in December 2019, the use of the term "decriminalisation" and "despenalización" on Twitter was more frequent and more important than one year later, whereas the use of the term "legal" increased and gained in significance within the one year. In both cases, the overall amount of tweets increased towards the end of the month. In September, however, this spike was less high, but lasted for longer than in December 2020. In December 2020, the spike in tweets in Mexico can probably also be explained by the legalisation of abortion in Argentina as the law was passed by the Senate on December 30th, 2020.

The use of key terms in Argentina for December 2020 shows the same spike as the Twitter data for Mexico in December 2020, a clear spike at the end of the month with over 12,000 tweets (compared to just over 700 in Mexico).

A second graph gives us a better insight into the terms used throughout that month in Argentina. It clearly shows that "legal" was the dominant term used throughout the month, in line with the data on Mexico for December 2020. This could also indicate the influence the debate in Argentina has on the terminology used in Mexico, using the term legalisation instead of decriminalisation after 2019 (see Demography Mexico December 2020 (2) below). However, the data also indicates that the church ("iglesia") played an important role in twitter posts on abortion at different times of the month with two clear spikes at the end of December (dark yellow). Such a spike cannot be detected in the Twitter data for Mexico for the same month even though the term does seem to appear in the graph around the same time (here in dark red), as the graph below indicates. This same trend has also been identified in the Topic Modelling for MediaCloud,  where the analysis for Argentina showed Topic 15 related to the church whereas Mexico did not.

Overall, the demography analysis suggests that the debate in Mexico is influenced by the debate in Argentina, in numbers and in vocabulary used. The debate in Mexico has shifted between 2019 and 2020, away from decriminalisation towards promoting the idea of legalisation, which is also in line with the data obtained from Argentina. Moreover, even though the church is mentioned both in Argentina and Mexico, it seems to play a significantly more important role in Argentina than it does in Mexico. After looking at the other results obtained, these findings will be compared and put into context with the other observed trends and the hypotheses explored in our investigation.

Abortion laws in Latin America are some of the most restrictive in the world. Across the region, some countries ban abortion with punishments of up to 40 years in prison (El Salvador). El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and the Dominican Republic ban abortion even in case of rape or health risks for the mother.  Other countries, including Brazil, allow legal abortions only in cases of rape or health risks for the mother.   The map below illustrates the current abortion restrictions across the region.

Restrictive abortion laws have detrimental consequences for women across the region, including health risks, also related to clandestine abortions, the threat of prison sentences, enforced maternity and increasing inequality between people that can afford decent clandestine abortions and others that cannot.  “Women with the greatest risk of death and sequelae from unsafe abortions are young, indigenous and black, and living in poor urban or rural areas with less access to formal education and less information on sexual and reproductive health and contraceptive methods, besides being more exposed to abusive relationships and/or to being victims of sexual violence” which demonstrates that the risk of illegal abortion is not shared equally across the population. Statistics indicate that women have abortions, if legal or not, and that legalisation is therefore often a matter of saving a woman’s life while restrictive laws impose signifiant health risks. Chile, with one of the strictest abortion laws in South America, also has the highest abortion rate in proportion to its female population. In South America, yearly, 30 out of 1000 women aged between 15 and 45 undergo an abortion, most of them illegal and in unsafe conditions.

Latin American feminists and women's organisations have spent many years fighting for the legalisation of abortion across the region.  This has led to important achievements at regional and national levels, most importantly the recently passed national abortion law in Argentina, but also smaller gains such as the Chilean’s success in visibilising femicides and the importance of respecting women and reproductive rights which could lead to possible considerations in the upcoming constitution drafting process.  In public debates, the topics of abortion and reproductive rights often coincide with growing concerns about femicides. “Outrage at worsening gender violence in Latin America, where the number of femicides has doubled in five years, has also spread awareness of the abortion rights movement and fuelled demands for recognition of women’s rights in a conservative, male-dominated society”.  Social media has played an important role in spreading the demands of women's movements and united efforts across the region as it allowed to bypass traditionally established media, often controlled by the establishments in Latin America.  However, the Catholic Church remains a strong actor in the region and categorically rejects the legalisation of abortion. The Church argues that in the end it is killing a human being which goes against the moral code of God and therefore does not align with catholic beliefs.  Hence, not only have feminist and women's movements increased their activism but conservative and religious groups have also continued to advocate for continued restrictions and achieve widespread success in limiting reproductive rights.

The regional landscape is increasingly divided along ideological lines. Despite the Americas having some of the most progressive regional human rights institutions, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACtHR) and the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, there remains a clear lack of consensus on any issues touching so-called 'gender ideology'. The 2018 Advisory Opinion of the IACtHR on gender identity, equality and non-discrimination for same-sex couples provoked one of the most recent conservative and religious backlashes in the region, due to its expansive interpretations of these issues, even if it is not specifically on abortion.
Ibid.
Ibid.

Argentina has been a pioneer in the region with regards to realising the agenda of the modern feminist social movement. Among other initiatives, it has legislated for female political quotas (2017),   transgender worker quotas (2020),  passed legislation on comprehensive sexual education (ESI) in schools (2006),  legalised same sex marriage (2010),  and passed a world standard gender identity law removing medical requirements for gender identity (2012).  Nonetheless, the success of the national abortion law in December 2020 was in the face of sustained domestic backlash,  considering that the recent feminist push for legalisation began over 15 years ago.

In 2003 the green bandana became the symbol of the Argentinian feminist movement.  A year later the Campaign for Safe, Free and Legal Abortion was created, and since 2007 the movement has presented legislation to the Argentinian House of Representatives each year. The first time the legislation was considered by the government was over 10 years later in 2018, when it was narrowly defeated in the Upper House.  Women's movements across the country have been organising and holding conferences followed by long marches often in front of public offices since the late 70s to 80s. The Madres de la Plaza de Mayo (Mothers of Plaza de Mayo) is an early example of the use of symbolic bandanas, and organised marches taking place outside of public offices for a cause.

However, these tactics have not been lost on the opponents of the feminist agenda, who unite under the light blue bandana (pañuelo celeste). Long marches have been just as common, however, given the variety of different organisations under the bandana, a lack of coordination between them has resulted in a less forceful anti-rights message.   A variety of opponents of abortion hint at the lack of implementation in other progressive projects on the feminist agenda like the ESI, which remains stagnant in many provinces of the country.

The Ni Una Menos movement (Not One [Woman] Less) significantly helped to create a broader social movement around the feminist agenda both domestically and regionally. The elasticity of the motto has allowed it gain traction across the region with numerous Ni Una Menos marches in Chile, Mexico and Uruguay.  The growing strength of the movement largely helped the law be presented to the House of Representatives in 2018 and its momentum increased after violence against women spiked during lockdowns from the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.  By December of the same year millions demonstrated in Buenos Aires leading to its narrow but historic approval on 30 December (the vote count can be seen in the figure below).

The Ni Una Menos movement is a reference to preventable female deaths occurring not only during clandestine abortions, but also the large number of femicides which have recently been gaining more publicity. Even before the Ni Una Menos movement, Soccoristas en Red maintained a link between preventable female deaths and female health. Soccoristas en Red was an organisation which was set up in 2012 to accompany women wanting to do clandestine abortions in an attempt to assuage the dangers and prevent the death of women in need of abortions. Importantly, the Campaign for free, safe and legal abortion also retained a strong connection to female health.

Every year, an estimate of between 500,000 to one million women and girls undergo (illegal or legal) abortion in Mexico, up to 30% of all yearly pregnancies (estimates from 2005); clandestine abortions are among the leading causes of maternal mortality in the country (estimated to be the fourth highest), greatly impacting women’s health.

Abortion laws in Mexico remain highly restrictive. On the federal level, abortion is considered a crime in the country, which makes it punishable for both, practitioners and women. Depending on the circumstances, a prison sentence between 1 to 6 years can be issued according to federal law in place since 1931, but suspending all penalties when an abortion follows rape.  Nonetheless, federal law matters little when it comes to abortion in Mexico, which is mainly regulated at the state level. This results in a “patchwork of state restrictions” making abortion legal in a few and illegal in the majority of states.  The map below illustrates the differences in regulations on abortion across the country. Only the state of Mexico City and, since September 2019, Oaxaca legalised voluntary abortion in all cases; all other states have differing degrees of legislation on legal abortion; from legal abortion in case of health risks or economic reasons, for example, to complete criminalisation (except in the case of rape). The scale goes from very restricted (“muy restrictivos”) in Guanajuato and Querétaro to legal abortion before the 12th week of pregnancy (“Aborto libre antes la semana 12”) in Mexico City (and most recently also Oaxaca).   The state of Oaxaca only recently passed a new law and therefore still appears as orange in this map (20.), but it is now one of the two states in Mexico that allows legal abortion before the 12th week of pregnancy.

The support for less restrictive abortion laws in Mexico has been rising. Polls indicated that as overall attitudes in Latin America shift, Mexico’s population is more open to abortion in 2020 than ever before, with 48% of the population supporting abortion in November compared to 28% in March 2020.

However, current president Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador declined to position himself in respect, classifying the issue as a “matter for public consultation”.  And despite many achievements by feminist and women's rights movements, the pro-life movement in Mexico remains very strong. Employing different strategies, including political lobbying, campaigns on different media outlets, and raising funds globally, they have been highly effective in influencing public opinion and political decision-makers. Mexico remains a stronghold of such counter-campaigns and many citizens justify their pro-life stance with traditional, often religious arguments.  These two opposing camps have been discussing the issue of legal abortion in Mexico since the 1980s. Government officials, political party members, social movement leaders and the Catholic Church have participated in intense political debates, demonstrating different strategies in the fight for the control over the female body.
Ibid.
Reproducción Asistida Org; (n.d.). Aborto en los estados de México. https://www.reproduccionasistida.org/interrupcion-legal-del-embarazo-en-mexico/aborto-en-los-estados-de-mexico/.
Ibid.

This section explores the framing of the abortion debate in print media in both Mexico and Argentina. Using cortext, a list of most frequent terms was extracted from both Mexico and Argentina's print media corpus. The terms were then cleaned and merged together to allow for a side-by-side comparison of the abortion debate in both countries using semantic network analysis (see table below). In addition to print media, semantic network analysis was also used to examine tweets at two different points in time in Mexico (September 2019 and December 2020) and once in Argentina (December 2020). The legalisation of abortion in Argentina in December 2020 might inform or influence discussions on abortion in Mexico, and examining tweets from Mexico pre- and post-legalization of abortion in Argentina should highlight any shifts in the discourse in the country.

The network analysis maps were produced using Cortext Network Mapping Analysis. The distributional proximity measure was used to produce both maps. The final proximity threshold was set at 0.50 with 300 corresponding nodes for both Mexico and Argentina.
Mexico Semantic Network Map, Mediacloud: Map explorer.
The Mexican network map produced six main clusters as the following:

Pro-life cluster (favor de la vida): Prominent nodes include nuestro país (our country), derecho a la vida (right to life), ser humano (human being), ideología de género (gender ideology), momento de la concepción (moment of conception).

Bill (proyecto de ley): Violación (rape), marea verde (green tide), clandestinos (unsafe abortion), profesionales de la salud (healthcare professionals), favor de la legalización (in favour of legalisation).

Women's health (salud de la mujer): Derechos de las mujeres (women's rights), derechos reproductivos (reproductive rights), vida de las mujeres (women's life), educación sexual (sex education), abortos inseguros (unsafe abortions).

Gender equality and reproductive health (salud sexual y reproductiva & igualdad de género): salud pública (public health), método anticonceptivo (contraceptives), mortalidad materna (maternal mortality), igualdad de género (gender equality).

Violence against women and feminist marches (violencia hacia las mujeres & marcha feminista): violencia de género (gender violence), redes sociales (social media), movimiento feminista (feminist movement), lucha feminista (feminist struggle).
Argentina Semantic Network Map, Mediacloud: Map explorer.
The Argentinian network map produced five main clusters as the following:

Maternal mortality & health (muertes maternas & vida humana): Prominent nodes include clandestinos (unsafe abortion), salud pública (public health), mortalidad materna (maternal mortality), favor de la despenalización (in favour of decriminalization), favor de la vida (pro-life).
Health system (sistema de salud): Federal judge (juez federal), human rights (derechos humanos), gender violence (violencia de género), acceso a (access to).

Product of rape and women's lives (producto de una violación & vida de las mujeres): Legal interruption (interrupción legal), profesionales de la salud (healthcare professionals), salud sexual y reproductiva (sexual and reproductive health), objeción de conciencia (right to refuse participation).
Endorsements and votes in favor (media sanción & votos a favor): Frente de todos (political party), Cámara de Diputados (Chamber of Deputies), embarazo hasta la semana (pregnancy up to week).

Feminist movement and feminist struggle (movimiento feminista & lucha feminista): Green tide (marea verde), women's movement (movimiento de mujeres), sex education (educación sexual), sexual abuse (abuso sexual).
Mexico Semantic Network Map, Twitter, December 2020: Map explorer.
Prominent clusters include legal abortion, pro-life, and women's health (unsafe abortions).
Argentina Semantic Network Map, Twitter, December 2020: Map explorer.
Prominent clusters include legalization of abortion, pro-life, and votes on abortion.
Mexico Semantic Network Map, Twitter, September 2019: Map explorer.
Prominent clusters include maternal mortality (causes of death), Green Tide day, marches in favour of abortion, pro-life, and violence against women.
Observations

The semantic network analysis places abortion in the frame of (women's) health in both Argentina and Mexico. To advance the legalisation of abortion, and to appeal to pro-life movements, abortion is framed as a women's health issue in Argentina and Mexico. This is distinct from the framing of abortion as grounded in the right to choice and privacy as it exists in the United States. The framing of abortion as a women's health issue is evident in discussions about the consequences of clandestine abortions such as maternal mortality, and the recasting of abortion as part and parcel to women's right to health (derecho a la salud). In the semantic network analysis, the clusters for women's health are prominent for both Argentina and Mexico, containing words such as reproductive health, maternal mortality and unsafe abortions. The women's health cluster provides links between the pro-life and pro-choice clusters for both countries. The theme of women's health as a cluster is the direct result of leveraging reproductive rights, human rights, and public health as lobbying tools to reform restrictive abortion laws. This advocacy method is particularly true for Mexico, where there is no legal ground to leverage as abortion is yet to be legalised in the country, therefore prompting a need for advocacy on the basis of human and women's rights outside of the legal framework.

The debate around abortion is more contentious and polarised in Mexico than in Argentina. In Argentina, the pro-life and pro-choice clusters are interconnected and share mutual nodes via the clusters for women's health. In Mexico, the pro-life and pro-choice clusters are less connected, showing fewer links to the issue of women's health and reproductive rights. This reflects the lack of societal consensus in Mexico and the wide variability in views when it comes to legalizing abortion. In comparison, Argentina shows greater cohesion, which reflects a more advanced stage of the debate as abortion was legalised in Argentina in December 2020. The status of abortion as a highly contentious and dividing issue in Mexico remains an obstacle to the legalisation of abortion in the country.

Between the periods of December 2019 and December 2020, there was greater attention being paid to the legalisation of abortion in Mexico, particularly as it coincides with Argentina's own formal legalisation of abortion in December 2020. After conducting a semantic network analysis based on tweets at two different points in time in Mexico (September 2019 and December 2020), the latter showed a larger cluster for the legalisation of abortion in comparison to one year earlier, with specific mentions being made to Argentina (senado argentino, mujeres argentinas, hermanas argentinas). This reflects a shift in the framing of abortion towards legalization in Mexico, as evident in the Demography Analysis, as well as potential efforts to capitalise on the legalization of abortion in Argentina to campaign for similar measures to be taken at a federal level in Mexico.
The following section outlines the data collection strategies for MediaCloud and Twitter, including search queries, time frames, and initial descriptive statistics.

The Data collection on MediaCloud was conducted for Mexico and Argentina separately, covering a time frame between January 2015 and April 2021. This offers a good overview of the debate around abortion in the two countries throughout the last five years. The search queries used for the collection include:
for Mexico: "Aborto AND México AND (legal* OR despenalización) AND (mujer* OR embarazo*)"
for Argentina: "Aborto AND Argentina AND (legal* OR despenalización) AND (mujer* OR embarazo*)"

The countries itself were included in the query to filter newspaper articles related to the national situation instead of news on regional or global developments. A rather extensive search query also ensures the accuracy and relevance of the collected newspaper data and therefore allows for a more targeted analysis.  The media sources consulted include national, state, and local level newspapers in Mexico and Argentina, respectively.
The Obtained Data

The dataset obtained for Mexico has a total number of entries of 8891 newspaper articles. The dataset includes big national and regional newspaper outlets including, for example, El Diario (national level), Animalpolítico (national level), El Sol (state level), El Guardián (state level), El Heraldo (state level), Sin Embargo (national level), Coahuila (state level), and La Vanguardia (national level). These outlets include some conservative/traditional ones, for example El Guardián and El Heraldo, and other more liberal/progressive outlets including Animalpolítico.

For Argentina, the final dataset contains 18773 entries. The significantly larger dataset here already indicates the first difference between the two countries. Overall, the topic seems to be more discussed in Argentinian newspapers than in Mexico. One explanation for this is the legalization of abortion in December 2020, but it might also indicate that the topic is more accepted in Argentina, even among more conservative print media outlets. Obviously, the newspaper articles from the 30th of December (the day the law was passed) are vast and most mention the law and politicians giving statements regarding their position towards the law. Some of the main media outlets represented in the data include the conservative outlets Infobae, La Nación and Clarín but also more center and liberal/progressive outlets such as Crónica and Página12 (center).
A detailed analysis of the different keywords and clusters found in the extracted newspaper data follows below under the data results section.
The data collection for Twitter was also conduced separately for Mexico and Argentina. However, due to the large number of tweets, we had to focus on a shorter time period than for MediaCloud.

The following graph shows the evolution of the google searches for the word "abortion" in Argentina over the past five years (the period covered in our MediaCloud dataset). It becomes evident that there are two big spikes. The first is a spike in 2018,  when a bill for the legalisation of abortion was first put on the legislative agenda in Argentina. The second spike is in December 2020, the month that this law was passed.

We use the search query "argentina aborto lang:es until:2020-12-31 since:2020-12-01" to extract tweets talking about abortion ("aborto") in Argentina. In addition, we add the constraint that the tweets should be in Spanish, to exclude international news coverage e.g. from the U.S. on this topic and instead focus on what the debate in Argentina itself is like. In doing so, we obtain a large corpus with 57,140 tweets. We import this dataset to cortext. However, when analysing it critically we find that while most tweets were sent from Argentina, there is also a substantial amount of tweets from other countries, mainly Venezuela, Chile, Ecuador, Peru, and Spain.

Hence, in a second step, we use the list builder feature on cortext to find the top 300 most used locations these tweets were sent from.  We edit this list to include a column specifying for each individual location if this location is in Argentina or not. Following that, we index the corpus with these tweets. In a last step, we use the query feature to drop all of those tweets from the corpus that were sent from locations confirmed to be outside Argentina. The tweets from users which did not specify a location remain, in order to not decrease our dataset too much. While not completely accurate, we ensure in this way that the majority of the tweets in our dataset for Argentina come from Argentinians. This leaves us with 44,878 tweets.

An analysis with Excel (sorting, filtering, deleting duplicates, subtotal of column without duplicates, etc.) shows that over half of the tweets on abortion in Argentina from December 2020 were sent on December 30th, the day that abortion was legalised in the country. While over the course of the month of December many people voiced their opinions (only about 37% of the tweets in our dataset between December 1 and December 29 were the second or a further tweet sent from a user), this changed on December 30th, where over 50% of the tweets in our dataset came from users who had tweeted about abortion in Argentina at least once before on that same day. This highlights the importance of this decision to legalise abortion, which fuelled the debate and brought about passionate responses from both sides.

For Mexico, the google searches for the word "abortion" in the country over the past five years (the period covered in our MediaCloud dataset) show a less clear trend. We would have expected a spike in September 2019, when abortion was legalised in the state of Oaxaca, like it was the case for Argentina in December 2020. While there is a visible increase in attention around this time, the debate seems to not have gained a significant amount of attention on a national level.

We follow the same logic as for Argentina, using the same search query (of course replacing the word "Argentina" for "Mexico"), but the time period of September 2019, when the law was passed in the state of Oaxaca. This only yields 3,525 tweets (3,202 after cleaning the dataset to only include tweets from Mexico, as described in detail above for Argentina). In addition, we hence also collect tweets for December 2020, assuming that the legalisation in Argentina might have had some spillover effects on Mexico. However, for this month we only obtain 2,560 tweets (2,442 after cleaning). Trying to produce a bigger corpus for Mexico as well, we run a third search query scraping all tweets on abortion in Mexico for the full years of 2019 and 2020. This yields 27,779 tweets in total (26,438 after cleaning), which is still significantly less than the number observed for Argentina in just December 2020. But in the case of Mexico, almost all of the initially collected tweets were indeed composed by Mexicans, while for Argentina there had been many tweets from other Latin American countries and Spain as well, highlighting the transnational impact of the Ni Una Menos movement. A first finding from this data is therefore that the abortion debate in Mexico gets a lot less attention on Twitter both within the country and within the wider region than it does in Argentina. This is similar to the findings for MediaCloud, where there were also significantly more newspaper articles on the topic of abortion for Argentina than for Mexico.

Aiming to get a first broad view of the topics covered in the newspaper articles collected through MediaCloud that make up our corpus, we make use of topic modelling, which is based on the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) model. With this analysis, the large amount of text in our corpus is sorted into the largest topics covered by the newspapers. Furthermore, the analysis also shows the most important terms used within each topic. We use topic modelling techniques separately, once for the Mexican and once for the Argentinian newspaper articles. For both cases, we set the number of topics to 20, with a minimum frequency of words of 5, and a maximum frequency of 50 (in percentage of the total corpus), while ensuring that the language used is Spanish. In the following, we will analyse and compare the results of this analysis.
Mexico

Topic 16, the most common topic in the dataset for Mexican newspaper articles, is about health data. It is quite technical, mentioning a lot of numbers, percentages of the population, prevention programmes and their results. This topic includes statistics on health and gives first evidence for what we will later determine to be the main line of argumentation used by the pro-abortion movement in Mexico. In an effort to convince especially the conservative part of the population of their cause, they do not argue about ethics and feminism. Instead, they focus on health number and the percentage of the population who gets a secret, illegal, and hence dangerous abortion anyway – which as discussed earlier concerns between 500,000 to one million women and girls every year.

Topic 3, the second most common topic, is similar to the previous topic. Dealing with health more generally, it includes discussions about the access to health services, interrupting a pregnancy, rape, reproductive rights, health risks, sexual violence, and the access to free abortion. In contrast to Topic 16, it is less focused on numbers and instead also focuses on tough topics such as rape and sexual violence. The connection between rape and abortion is much discussed, since in theory, even though abortion is illegal in Mexico on a federal level, it is legal in cases of rape throughout the country. In practice, however, it is often difficult for women to access this service  .

Topic 11 deals with the topic of feminism, one of whose central agenda items is the fight for legal, safe, and free abortion (“aborto legal, seguro, y gratuito”). This topic includes newspaper coverage of marches organised by the pro-abortion movement, as well as collective protests among others against the problem of femicide. We expected this topic to be even more prominent and not only the third most common topic. The fact that this topic is only in third place could be evidence of a consciously chosen narrative of the debate in Mexico which focuses strongly on the health effects over the ethical discussion.

Interestingly, there is also one topic in Mexican newspaper articles about abortion that deals with Argentina. Topic 4 discusses Argentinian President Fernandez and the discussions around legalising abortion in Argentina, mentioning arguments of those in favour (“aprobar”), but also of those against (“rechazar”). The current law that was then being passed in Argentina was much discussed in Mexican media. Argentina as a standard bearer for progressive minority rights in the region evidently has an impact on its neighbours in the region. Additionally, this topic also mentions neighbouring Uruguay, where abortion has been legal since 2012.
Argentina

One of the main topics mentioned in Argentinian newspapers is of course the vote in favour of legalising abortion, passed by the National Congress in December 2020. Topic 2 talks about this vote, as well as the previous legal and political discussions on abortion. It deals both with the way specific senators felt about it, as well as the main statements by the two campaigns. The year 2018 also appears, which is the year that a national law for legalising abortion was first put on the legislative agenda in Argentina. With the success of the new legislation, abortion is now legal until the 14th week of pregnancy (“14ª semana de embarazo”), also explained within this topic.

Topic 7 is about sexual education and general politics. The public comprehensive sexual education program (Educación Sexual Integral) is another integral part of the Argentinian feminist agenda. The debate about the relevance of an abortion law in Argentinian society is linked to the criticism of 'gender ideology' proposed by its opponents. Opponents hold that many progressive laws are inherently ideological since they are passed but not implemented. The comprehensive sexual education bill (ESI) is one of these controversial bills which struggles to find a uniform and effective implementation 15 years after it was sanctioned. This explains why it is a side conversation of the general debate on abortion as well as part of the rhetoric of opponents. Mixed in with this topic are some general topical political questions such as the response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Similar to Topic 11 for Mexico, Topic 8 in Argentinian newspaper articles about abortion deals with feminist movements. In both cases, the most common word is feminism, and both talk about violence (“violencia”) against women and femicide (“femicidio”). Within this topic for Argentina, the discussion is already more advanced than in Mexico, debating if abortion should not only be legal, but also free of cost (“gratuito”). Keeping in mind that Argentina legalised abortion nationally during our analysed time period and Mexico did not, this seems sensible. Furthermore, this topic for the Argentinian case deals with justice for women, organised marches, and reclaiming the rights to decide on one’s body. Organised marches in Argentina took on a marathon-like character, during votes on legislation when they lasted over 24 hours, but otherwise they are a prominent historical feature of women's movements domestically since the 1990s.

Topic 15 is about the Catholic Church and religious beliefs more generally, which played an important role in the debate around legalising abortion in Argentina. This is the counter-movement, against the legalisation of abortion, i.e. “pro-life”. They talk about the Pope who is from Buenos Aires, yet played a minimised role in the counter movement despite his high profile. In addition, they talk about the head of the Catholic Church within Argentina, as well as the fight for every human life. Moreover, the bishops (“obispos”) seem to play an important role in the debate, with e.g. “monseñor Oscar Ojea”, head of the Argentine Episcopal Conference (CEA) and Bishop of San Isidro, being cited in many articles. These findings hint at the wide transnational nature of the counter-movement.

An analysis of Twitter and domestic newspapers has helped to draw connections between theory, regional contexts, and local public debates on the feminist movement and its counter-movement in Argentina vs. in Mexico. The public debates in the two countries have more similarities than differences, which bodes well for the future success of the feminist agendas in the region, given the large cultural influence of the two countries in our analysis. The strategies employed by different actors to promote their ideas is the most interesting discovery our analysis of social media has uncovered.

First, the pro-life clusters were weaker in our Twitter database and stronger in the data from MediaCloud. This lends support to the idea that traditional media is more conservative than social media, most likely due to demographic differences. Another interesting finding from several of our data analyses reflects a possible shift in strategy. The pro-choice camp is choosing to frame the legalisation of abortion as a public health issue rather than a feminist issue. By depoliticising reproductive rights and focusing on the dangers and mortality rates associated with clandestine abortions, pro-abortion activists find common ground with opponents and make the pro-choice argument harder to categorically reject.

Interestingly, the conversation around abortion appears to be more polarised in Mexico than in Argentina. In Argentina, the pro-life and pro-choice clusters experience higher degrees of connectivity by way of women’s health issues. The fact that there are far fewer links between the two nodes in Mexico may reflect a deeply divided society on the topic of abortion or Argentina’s higher advancement in the arena of reproductive rights. The latter can be a good thing for other abortion movements in the region. The formal legalization of abortion in Argentina in December of 2020 sparked more discourse on abortion in Mexico during that time. It also influenced the conversation, as evidenced by Mexicans moving away from the term “decriminalisation” and towards “legalisation”.

While the transnational nature of the feminist movements in Latin America is clearly reflected in social media chatter, heterogeneity can be found in public abortion debates across countries. The Mexican pro-life lobby is very strong, with half of the population still against abortion rights. Given our findings, we suggest that Mexican pro-choice activists continue to use simple, health-related statistics as part of their rhetoric, encouraging communication between the two sides and keeping the abortion conversation away from the feared “gender ideology” and radical feminist discourse. While it might seem counter-intuitive to divorce abortion from the feminist cause, it may be key to enabling incremental steps towards progress.
This section shows some examples of prominent tweets from our datasets.
Argentina
“Remember when you got your first green bandana? Well, today it's law. Legal abortion in Argentina. 💚 ” – @maicapp

This is the most liked tweet in our dataset for Argentina, celebrating the legalisation of abortion on the day the law was passed. As described earlier, the "green bandana" is a classic symbol for the pro-abortion movement in Argentina.
“38 votes in favour
29 against
1 abstention
ABORTION IS LAW IN ARGENTINA
💚 💚 💚 💚” – @PorAbortoLegal

This tweet is from an account dealing exclusively with the topic of legalising abortion in Argentina. It was posted right after the vote passed, summarising the results. It is the most reblogged tweet in our dataset for Argentina.
“Abortion is law in Argentina!
The Argentinian Senate approved the law on voluntary termination of pregnancy!
WE MADE HISTORY!”
picture: “Argentina said goodbye to clandestine abortions!” – Amnesty International Argentina

The Argentine branch of the international human rights organisation Amnesty International focused this tweet on the fact that the new law protects women from dangerous clandestine abortions. This tweet was the second most retweeted from our dataset for Argentina.

“Did you know that the K's (= legislative agenda of Kirchnerismo, referring to the previous two Presidents, to whom the current President Alberto Fernandez is closely tied) abortion bill would allow abortions up to the ninth month of pregnancy? This is provided for in article 4, under two very simple grounds for abortion. Thus, if the law is passed, it would be legal in Argentina to murder children at any stage of the pregnancy.” – @AgustinLaje

This tweet is from the counter-movement, written by Argentinian writer, political scientist and philosopher Agustín Laje. He is a known supporter of the pro-life movement who in this tweet is spreading fake information on the extent of the government plans for the abortion bill. His tweet was the most popular tweet from the counter-movement in our dataset.

“In the midst of the biggest crisis in history, two public holidays in honour of the virgin in the week we deal with abortion. If Argentina did not exist, it would not have to be invented.” – @osvaldobazan
This tweet is another popular tweet that is more critical, showing the divide between an Argentina that has deep roots in the Catholic Church but also legalised abortion.
Mexico
“THEY DID IT! The decriminalisation of abortion in Oaxaca was approved with 24 votes in favour and 10 votes against. Oaxaca becomes the second state with Legal Termination of Pregnancy (ILE).

It's going to be defeated, it's being defeated! We continue to win battles and it will be law in all of Mexico!
#LegalAbortionOaxaca” –  @marianaliru

This is the most popular retweeted tweet for the September 2019 dataset for Mexico, celebrating the legalisation of abortion in the state of Oaxaca that month and encouraging the supporters to keep fighting for nationwide legalisation.

“In Oaxaca abortion is already legal and safe, and Monterrey, which is the great city, the great industrial capital of the country, where the GDP of Mexico is located, continues with its damn backward and stupid mentality, what a shame.” – @mellamonati

This is the most liked tweet from the September 2019 dataset for Mexico, as expected focusing on the legalisation of abortion in the state of Oaxaca. The author criticises that in other important states such as Monterrey such legislation has not yet been passed.
“The amnesty law decriminalises abortion nationwide and supports abortion clinics!
This is unfortunately how the pro-abortion Morena party (= the ruling president’s party) wants to kill babies by lying to the people of Mexico.”
#NOtoAbortion
#Let’sSaveBothLifes
#MexicoIsProLife” – @CarlosLealMx

This tweet is the most popular tweet from the counter-movement in September 2019, written by a deputy from an opposition, conservative party. It is factually incorrect, since the amnesty law he mentions only applies to past incidences of illegal abortion in specific cases and does in no way legalise abortion in the future.
“Abortion in Mexico:
In Mexico City and Oaxaca it is decriminalised up to 12 weeks.
Rape is a ground for abortion in all parts of the country.
According to the general law on victims, NOM 046 and two rulings of the SCJN it is a right for victims of sexual violence.
...” – @appleninde

This is the most popular tweet for December 2020. It is the first of a thread by a lesbian, feminist, attorney and blogger Ninde Moire, who in this thread explains the legal situation in terms of the right to abortion in Mexico.
“Abortion will be legal in Argentina and later in Mexico.
No one can stop this tide!
#LegalAbortionNow” – @EstefaniaVeloz

This tweet confirms our hypothesis that the legalisation of abortion in Argentina had an effect on the debate in Mexico. It is the second most popular tweet for Mexico in December 2020, referring to the “green tide”, i.e. pro-abortion movements all over the continent.
“Mexico is more afraid of equal marriage and decriminalisation of abortion than of COVID 🤡” – @davidmtzt

This is the most popular tweet in the twitter debate in Mexico for all of 2019-2020. Similar to the last tweet shown for the case of Argentina, it highlights, in a pointed way, how deeply rooted the fear of legalising abortion is in parts of the Mexican society.
“Mexico:
Does not promote sexual education
Does not allow adoption by same-sex couples
Its process for adopting a child is almost impossible.
Criminalises abortion
Does not provide justice for rapists and lets them go free.” – @danasofia_rdz
This second most popular tweet for 2019-2020 shows that in Mexico, abortion is often discussed within the context of other feminist and social issues.

“Some senators and deputies in Mexico want to decriminalise abortion, even for 13-year-old girls. It is unbelievable that they intend to approve mothers killing their children. Let's respect life at all stages of development. Zero votes for abortion!
#MexicoCeleste #MexicoIsProLife” – @EVerastegui

This tweet is an example for narratives from the counter-movement. It was written by Mexican actor and pro-life activist Eduardo Verástegui, whose tweets about abortion are some of the most popular ones in our 2019-2020 dataset. He is of the opinion, that 13-year-old girls should not have the right to abortion. The hashtags he uses are typical for the counter-movement, utilising the colour celeste (light blue) in opposition to the colour green used by the pro-abortion movement.

variable="issued"> <date-part name="year"/> </date> </if> <else> <text term="no date" form="short"/> </else> </choose> </macro> <macro name="edition"> <choose> <if is-numeric="edition"> <group delimiter=" "> <number variable="edition" form="ordinal"/> <text term="edition" form="short"/> </group> </if> <else> <text variable="edition" suffix="."/> </else> </choose> </macro> <macro name="locators"> <choose> <if type="article-journal article-magazine article-newspaper" match="any"> <group prefix=", " delimiter=", "> <group> <text variable="volume" font-style="italic"/> <text variable="issue" prefix="(" suffix=")"/> </group> <text variable="page"/> </group> </if> <else-if type="bill book chapter graphic legal_case legislation motion_picture paper-conference report song" match="any"> <group prefix=" (" suffix=")" delimiter=", "> <text macro="edition"/> <group> <text term="volume" form="short" plural="true" text-case="capitalize-first" suffix=" "/> <number variable="number-of-volumes" form="numeric" prefix="1-"/> </group> <group> <text term="volume" form="short" text-case="capitalize-first" suffix=" "/> <number variable="volume" form="numeric"/> </group> <group> <label variable="page" form="short" suffix=" "/> <text variable="page"/> </group> </group> </else-if> </choose> </macro> <macro name="citation-locator"> <group> <label variable="locator" form="short"/> <text variable="locator" prefix=" "/> </group> </macro> <citation et-al-min="6" et-al-use-first="1" et-al-subsequent-min="3" et-al-subsequent-use-first="1" disambiguate-add-year-suffix="true" disambiguate-add-names="true" disambiguate-add-givenname="true" givenname-disambiguation-rule="primary-name" collapse="year"> <sort> <key macro="author"/> <key macro="issued-year"/> </sort> <layout prefix="(" suffix=")" delimiter="; "> <group delimiter=", "> <text macro="author-short"/> <text macro="issued-year"/> <text macro="citation-locator"/> </group> </layout> </citation> <bibliography hanging-indent="true" et-al-min="8" et-al-use-first="7" entry-spacing="0" line-spacing="2"> <sort> <key macro="author"/> <key macro="issued-year" sort="ascending"/> </sort> <layout> <group suffix="."> <text macro="author" suffix="."/> <text macro="issued" suffix=" "/> <group delimiter=". "> <text macro="title"/> <group> <text macro="container-contributors"/> <text macro="secondary-contributors"/> <group delimiter=", "> <text variable="container-title" font-style="italic"/> <text variable="collection-title"/> </group> </group> </group> <text macro="locators"/> <group delimiter=", " prefix=". "> <text macro="event"/> <text macro="publisher"/> </group> </group> <text macro="access" prefix=". "/> </layout> </bibliography> </style>
